g.text: We now illustrate the use of the
described in Section 2, taking as an example MoS
layered crystals which belong to the transition metal
dichalcogenide crystal family. Although the structure of MoS
was determined about 100 years ago and this layered crystal
was used mainly as a dry lubricant, the new wave of interest in
transition metal dichalcogenides began after the discovery of
graphene. This interest, apart from the fundamental proper-
ties of monolayers, is connected with the observation of the
direct band gap of 1.8 eV at the
layer, even though the bulk MoS
with an indirect band gap of 1.2 eV. The transition to a direct
as a solar photovoltaic material owing to the drastic
enhancement of photoluminescence in the monolayer
compared with the bulk. Other crystals of the transition metal
Comprehensive reviews and many references to studies of
this material can be found in the work of Wang (2014),

(No. 194). In the bulk crystal, the metal atoms occupy the
) position and the sulfur atoms occupy the 4
, 2014). The layer group of a single layer
. The crystal structure of a single layer
is shown in Fig. 6. Atoms in the primitive unit cell of the layer
occupy the following Wyckoff positions: Mo (W) 1
). Note that the layer group of a single layer is also a
subgroup of the space group of the bulk crystal.
The phonon symmetry in these crystals has been studied by
introduced explicitly only by Evarestov (2015), Evarestov
(2014), the symmetry of single layers was
described in terms of the related space group
and, in addition, the authors applied a non-standard irrep
notation, which hinders the use and comparison of their
analysis of the phonon symmetry of a single MoS
